discourse_list.title: Proposal: Use excess USDC from the PSM to buy and burn MKR

content.content: The PSM can restore the peg but the problem is that it may require a high USDC debt ceiling that many are not comfortable with and in theory could create a fatal risk for MKR hodlers.   Let’s say, for example, that we needed 200m USDC debt ceiling in the PSM to restore the peg but we didn’t want to have more than 50m USDC debt ceiling. We could then take the 150m excess USDC and start to run our standard FLAP auctions to buy and burn MKR, which would remove all excess USDC risk from the protocol.  Yes- this would create unbacked DAI which would have the exact effect we want in this scenario- lower the DAI price back to the peg.   It would also provide a massive boost to the MKR price, creating more confidence in the system. Now, let’s say that we overshoot and having unbacked Dai quickly results in Dai falling below the peg.   What would happen then?  We would then raise SF but instead of using the excess Dai to run FLAP auctions, we would first retire the unbacked Dai. Essentially, by using the excess USDC to buy and burn MKR when Dai is above the peg, we would simply be borrowing from future SF income to buy and burn MKR in the present, when we most need it since there is essentially no income to support MKR when SF is at zero and Dai is above the peg.
content.GPT-summary: The author proposes using excess USDC from the PSM to buy and burn MKR, which would remove excess USDC risk from the protocol and boost the MKR price. The proposal also addresses potential issues with unbacked DAI and outlines a plan to retire it. A 3rd party could provide constructive criticism or audit the proposal.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal

content.content: MKR’s market cap sits in the $400m range. In a situation where DAI scales to the billions, the system could quickly run amuck, where we need to print billions of MKR to cover billions of stablecoins wrapped through the PSM/PSN. The PSM acts like a wrapper (and I think this is a fear of some people: Dai turns into a wrapper) and should help the protocol scale. Every time an individual converts from USDC to DAI using the wrapper, the system-wide vault possesses 1 USDC for every 1 DAI converted. In this instance, the DAI is backed by 1 USDC (in old-terms, think of it as a vault with 0% LR, 0% stability fee, and some % transaction fee) and is not necessary to use our recollateralization resource: MKR. This PSM does transfer the risk of minting DAI from stablecoins from the vault holders to MKR holders. The only instance in which MKR would need to be printed is if USDC’s value dropped below $0/Blacklist, the protocol-wide USDC vault linked to the PSM module. Other than that, I don’t see another instance in which we would need to print MKR. If we were to use the system-wide vault’s USDC to purchase MKR like you said above, you’re assuming parity in liquidity and low-slippage. If the vault were to purchase $150m MKR (conversion from USDC to MKR like you said), this could easily triple MKR price. On paper, our MKR conversion could look like a sweet deal. If we had to sell this MKR (say we begin to unload the PSM), slippage becomes an issue. After selling the $150m MKR, we’re now left with only $130m MKR and we incur a $20m loss.

content.content: Having unbacked Dai is actually not that dissimilar from the situation that we have today.   Right now, when someone buys Dai they are paying $1.02 for an asset that is backed by only $1 worth of collateral.   Once you have unbacked Dai, you would just be lowering this ratio to paying e.g. $1.01 for an asset that is backed by $0.99 worth of collateral - and therefore it would rapidly lower the Dai price back down to the peg.   The main issue is that once the peg is restored, you need to be able to quickly retire the unbacked Dai.  This can be done by using the SF income or by minting and selling MKR.  This is why the proposal is essentially borrowing from future MKR income/burns to burn MKR in the situation we are in today when Dai is above the peg- but provides the advantage that it enables the peg to be rapidly restored using the PSM and the protocol does not need to take on the risk of holding high levels of stablecoins.

content.content: Well - keep in mind that this 500m excess USDC would first be used to buy and burn MKR, which would probably send MKR price into a very high range.  For this to happen, it would also mean that Dai would have to remain above its $1 peg even though it was backed by only $0.28 (2/7) in collateral, which is extremely unlikely.  But even if this happened and the peg was then restored, we would then slowly start minting MKR to buy back the unbacked Dai as well as using the incoming SF income to burn Dai until the system was back in surplus.   In reality, we would could also set limits on the initial MKR burn so that we would never have more than 10% of Dai supply be unbacked (in your example it is 70% of supply), so that the impact would be much more manageable. If we got to a situation where we could not restore the peg using the full USDC debt ceiling and having 10% unbacked dai, we are already in a severe failure mode and probably we need ES at that point anyway.
